column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.RoleAnnotation|roles
#Text=Ms.
#Text=Skare: Thank you, Mr.
#Text=President, for letting\r
#Text=NATO participate in this important debate.
#Text=I would\r
#Text=also like to thank the briefers for their excellent\r
#Text=presentations.
#Text=Civil society organizations have been instrumental\r
#Text=in promoting women's rights and gender equality.
#Text=To a large degree, it was thanks to civil society that\r
#Text=resolution 1325 (2000) on women and peace and security\r
#Text=saw the light of day 12 years ago.
#Text=As much as States\r
#Text=and intergovernmental organizations show leadership\r
#Text=in advancing that agenda, we have to recognize the\r
#Text=important role that members of civil society play as\r
#Text=opinion leaders and sources of information, as well as\r
#Text=in keeping us accountable.
#Text=While States have the primary responsibility\r
#Text=for ensuring the implementation of the resolutions\r
#Text=on women and peace and security, NATO, as a\r
#Text=political-military organization, is playing its part within\r
#Text=NATO-led operations and within our partnerships.
#Text=We\r
#Text=have a policy, we have an action plan and, together with\r
#Text=partners, we are turning words into deeds.
#Text=On the political level, NATO is actively encouraging\r
#Text=all its partners to adopt specific goals related to the\r
#Text=promotion of women, peace and security issues in the\r
#Text=various partnership programmes they develop with\r
#Text=our organization.
#Text=The overall aim is to raise awareness\r
#Text=and to work towards greater female participation in\r
#Text=the areas of defence and security.
#Text=Women are still\r
#Text=underrepresented in peace and reconciliation processes,\r
#Text=and we encourage States and our partners to ensure\r
#Text=women's participation in the prevention, management\r
#Text=and resolution of conflicts.
#Text=At the operational level, NATO and its operational\r
#Text=partners in the International Security Assistance\r
#Text=Force (ISAF) and Kosovo Force have demonstrated a\r
#Text=strong commitment to promoting the important role\r
#Text=that women can play, and have engaged with women\r
#Text=leaders and activists to understand their views and\r
#Text=perspectives.
#Text=The Alliance has gender advisers and\r
#Text=focal points at its various headquarters, as well as in\r
#Text=operational theatres in Afghanistan and Kosovo.
#Text=I work\r
#Text=with these dedicated people and see the significant\r
#Text=efforts they are making to mainstream resolution 1325\r
#Text=(2000) and related resolutions and to integrate the\r
#Text=gender perspective into operations.
#Text=Experience to date has shown that having gender\r
#Text=expertise, as well as having more female soldiers in\r
#Text=theatre, improves our ability to conduct operations\r
#Text=more effectively.
#Text=For example, we have learned that\r
#Text=female soldiers in Afghanistan are at times able to better\r
#Text=connect with members of the population otherwise\r
#Text=closed off from their male colleagues.
#Text=This has led to\r
#Text=greater awareness of the specific situation and area,\r
#Text=and led to better dialogue and understanding between\r
#Text=NATO forces and the local community.
#Text=Our experience\r
#Text=has also shown that training and education are strategic\r
#Text=tools for security forces and for defence and security\r
#Text=sector reform.
#Text=Ifused correctly, they can be major force\r
#Text=multipliers, as the attitudes of those trained can spread\r
#Text=to walks of life beyond the security sphere.
#Text=As Council members are aware, the mandate of\r
#Text=the ISAF mission was recently renewed, and the plans\r
#Text=to hand over full security responsibility from ISAF\r
#Text=forces to their Afghan counterparts are on course, as\r
#Text=reaffirmed at the Chicago Summit.
#Text=Throughout the\r
#Text=transition process and beyond, we will continue to\r
#Text=focus on gender-related training and to support the\r
#Text=recruitment and retention of women in the security\r
#Text=forces.
#Text=NATO works shoulder to shoulder with other\r
#Text=international organizations maintaining international\r
#Text=peace and security, and we seek to strengthen further\r
#Text=our cooperation with the United Nations and others to\r
#Text=make sure we learn from each other's experiences and\r
#Text=pave the way for greater efficiency and more results.
#Text=Since my appointment as the NATO Secretary\r
#Text=General's Special Representative for Women,\r
#Text=Peace and Security, I have had the great pleasure of\r
#Text=engaging in dialogue with women's associations in\r
#Text=the security sector, womens' rights activists, female\r
#Text=parliamentarians and other representatives of civil\r
#Text=society.
#Text=I intend to deepen this dialogue.
#Text=NATO and its member States remain committed\r
#Text=to upholding human rights and the rule of law.
#Text=As\r
#Text=we face up to the security challenges of the twenty-\r
#Text=first century, we will continue to work with partners\r
#Text=and other members of the international community to\r
#Text=achieve better security and the greater empowerment\r
#Text=of women.
